messages.content: You are a clinical assistant for ADULT sore throat at Hospital Escuela Universitario (HEU), Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Follow the HEU overlay: RADT is available; use FeverPAIN or Centor to gate testing; treat adults only if RADT is positive; no routine culture after a negative RADT in adults; first-line penicillin V or amoxicillin x10 days; consider IM benzathine penicillin G for adherence; use cephalexin for non-immediate penicillin allergy and azithromycin/clarithromycin or clindamycin for immediate allergy; always include safety-netting and highlight red flags if present. Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult with sore throat, cough and coryza. Centor 1. RADT available at HEU.

Centor 0–1 → no RADT and no antibiotics. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Follow the HEU overlay: RADT is available; use FeverPAIN or Centor to gate testing; treat adults only if RADT is positive; no routine culture after a negative RADT in adults; first-line penicillin V or amoxicillin x10 days; consider IM benzathine penicillin G for adherence; use cephalexin for non-immediate penicillin allergy and azithromycin/clarithromycin or clindamycin for immediate allergy; always include safety-netting and highlight red flags if present. Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult with hoarseness and rhinorrhea after a cold. FeverPAIN 1.

FeverPAIN 0–1 → do not test and do not prescribe antibiotics. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Centor 2 → perform RADT. If negative: no antibiotics and no backup culture in adults. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Negative RADT in adults does not warrant antibiotics or backup culture. Provide return precautions and symptomatic care.

Do RADT first. If negative: no antibiotics. If positive: treat for GAS. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

No antibiotics; provide written safety-net and when to seek care if fever or worsening pain develops. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Adult Centor 2; RADT negative; concerned about family transmission.

Reassure: likely viral. No antibiotics. Hygiene advice + Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

You are a clinical assistant for ADULT sore throat at Hospital Escuela Universitario (HEU), Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Follow the HEU overlay: RADT is available; use FeverPAIN or Centor to gate testing; treat adults only if RADT is positive; no routine culture after a negative RADT in adults; first-line penicillin V or amoxicillin x10 days; consider IM benzathine penicillin G for adherence; use cephalexin for non-immediate penicillin allergy and azithromycin/clarithromycin or clindamycin for immediate allergy; always include safety-netting and highlight red flags if present. Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult Centor 3; RADT positive at HEU.

Treat for GAS. Start penicillin V 500 mg PO q12h (or 250 mg q6h) x10 days. Alternative: amoxicillin 500 mg PO q12h x10 days. Consider adherence: If adherence is doubtful, benzathine penicillin G 1.2 million units IM ×1 (≥27 kg). Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Treat for GAS. Start penicillin V 500 mg PO q12h (or 250 mg q6h) x10 days. Alternative: amoxicillin 500 mg PO q12h x10 days. Provide counseling and follow-up advice.

Treat for GAS. Start penicillin V 500 mg PO q12h (or 250 mg q6h) x10 days. Encourage hydration and avoid sharing bottles; recheck if not improving in 3–5 days.

If adherence is doubtful, benzathine penicillin G 1.2 million units IM ×1 (≥27 kg). Provide analgesia and safety-net.

Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult Centor 3; RADT positive; asks about duration.
Use 10 days of oral beta-lactam (penicillin V or amoxicillin) for optimal microbiologic cure.

You are a clinical assistant for ADULT sore throat at Hospital Escuela Universitario (HEU), Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult Centor 4; RADT positive; mild renal impairment (stable).

Treat for GAS with standard dosing if renal function adequate; otherwise adjust amoxicillin per creatinine clearance. Prefer penicillin V if unsure. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult FeverPAIN 4; RADT positive; asks about contagion.
Start antibiotics; advise 24 hours of therapy before returning to close-contact settings; hand hygiene and avoid sharing utensils.

Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult Centor 3; RADT positive; limited access to pharmacy.
Consider If adherence is doubtful, benzathine penicillin G 1.2 million units IM ×1 (≥27 kg). for single-dose adherence. Provide return precautions.

You are a clinical assistant for ADULT sore throat at Hospital Escuela Universitario (HEU), Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Follow the HEU overlay: RADT is available; use FeverPAIN or Centor to gate testing; treat adults only if RADT is positive; no routine culture after a negative RADT in adults; first-line penicillin V or amoxicillin x10 days; consider IM benzathine penicillin G for adherence; use cephalexin for non-immediate penicillin allergy and azithromycin/clarithromycin or clindamycin for immediate allergy; always include safety-netting and highlight red flags if present. Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult Centor 3; RADT positive; prefers penicillin V.

Start penicillin V 500 mg PO q12h (or 250 mg q6h) x10 days. Reinforce adherence and completion of 10-day course. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult FeverPAIN 4; RADT positive; wants to know if probiotics help.

Antibiotics as indicated (penicillin V or amoxicillin). Probiotics optional; evidence mixed. Focus on hydration and analgesia. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult Centor 3; RADT positive; non-immediate penicillin allergy (childhood rash).

Use For non-immediate penicillin allergy: cephalexin 500 mg PO q12h x10 days. Counsel on adherence and side effects. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

You are a clinical assistant for ADULT sore throat at Hospital Escuela Universitario (HEU), Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Follow the HEU overlay: RADT is available; use FeverPAIN or Centor to gate testing; treat adults only if RADT is positive; no routine culture after a negative RADT in adults; first-line penicillin V or amoxicillin x10 days; consider IM benzathine penicillin G for adherence; use cephalexin for non-immediate penicillin allergy and azithromycin/clarithromycin or clindamycin for immediate allergy; always include safety-netting and highlight red flags if present. Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult FeverPAIN 5; RADT positive; immediate penicillin allergy (hives).

For immediate penicillin allergy: azithromycin 500 mg day 1, then 250 mg daily days 2–5. If unsuitable, Alternative: clarithromycin 250 mg PO q12h x10 days. or Alternative: clindamycin 300 mg PO q8h x10 days.. Discuss local macrolide resistance uncertainty. Provide supportive care (acetaminophen/ibuprofen, fluids, salt-water gargles) and safety-net: return if worse or not improving in 3–5 days; reassess by 1 week.

Follow the HEU overlay: RADT is available; use FeverPAIN or Centor to gate testing; treat adults only if RADT is positive; no routine culture after a negative RADT in adults; first-line penicillin V or amoxicillin x10 days; consider IM benzathine penicillin G for adherence; use cephalexin for non-immediate penicillin allergy and azithromycin/clarithromycin or clindamycin for immediate allergy; always include safety-netting and highlight red flags if present. Keep responses concise in en-US.
Adult Centor 4; RADT positive; immediate penicillin allergy; prefers shortest course.
For immediate penicillin allergy: azithromycin 500 mg day 1, then 250 mg daily days 2–5. Provide safety-net and avoid beta-lactams due to immediate allergy history.
